<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Indicate by check mark whether the registrants (1) have filed all reports required to be filed by Section 13 or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 during the preceding 12 months (or for such

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Indicate by check mark whether any of the registrants is a shell company (as defined in Rule 12b-2 of the Exchange Act). Yes </FONT><FONT style="font-family:sans-serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><font face="Wingdings 2">&#163;</font></FONT><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "> No </FONT><FONT style="font-family:sans-serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><font face="Wingdings 2">&#83;</font></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As of July 27, 2007, Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated had outstanding 254,283,335 shares of its sole class of Common Stock, without par value.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As of July 27, 2007, Public Service Electric and Gas Company had issued and outstanding 132,450,344 shares of Common Stock, without nominal or par value, all of which were privately held,
  beneficially and of record by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG Power LLC and PSEG Energy Holdings L.L.C. are wholly owned subsidiaries of Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated and meet the conditions set forth in General Instruction H(1) (a)
  and (b) of Form&nbsp;10-Q and are filing their respective Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q with the reduced disclosure format authorized by General Instruction H.</FONT></P>

    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      79</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top" bgcolor="#e5ffff">
    <TD><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      Item 6.</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">

  subject to risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated. Such statements are based on management&#146;s beliefs as well as assumptions made by and
  information currently available to management.   such words and similar expressions are intended to identify forward-looking statements. Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG
  Power LLC (Power) and PSEG Energy Holdings L.L.C. (Energy Holdings) undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information,
  future events or otherwise. The following review should not be construed as a complete list of factors that could affect forward-looking statements. In addition to any assumptions and other factors referred
  to specifically in connection with such forward-looking statements discussed above, factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contemplated in any forward-looking statements
  include, among others, the following:</FONT></P>

<p style="page-break-before: always">

    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>

  prospects, financial condition or results of operations. Undue reliance should not be placed on these forward-looking statements in making any investment decision. Each of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and
  Energy Holdings expressly disclaims any obligation or undertaking to release publicly any updates or revisions to these forward-looking statements to reflect events or circumstances that occur or arise or
  are anticipated to occur or arise after the date hereof. In making any investment decision regarding PSEG&#146;s, PSE&amp;G&#146;s, Power&#146;s and Energy Holdings&#146; securities, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings
  are not making, and you should not infer, any representation about the likely existence of any particular future set of facts or circumstances. The forward-looking statements contained in this report are
  intended to qualify for the safe harbor provisions of Section 27A of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, and Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended.</FONT></P>

    <TD><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      $</FONT></P></TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>

       371</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
  </TR>
</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">See Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">4</FONT></P>

      $</FONT></P></TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD align="right"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
       84</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
  </TR>

<P align="center" style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">See disclosures regarding PSEG Energy Holdings L.L.C. included in the<br>Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">16</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<PAGE>

<P align="center" style="margin:4.2mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B><a name=notes>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">This combined Form 10-Q is separately filed by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power LLC (Power) and PSEG
  Energy Holdings L.L.C. (Energy Holdings). Information contained herein relating to any individual company is filed by such company on its own behalf. PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each make
  representations only as to itself and make no representations as to any other company.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=note1>Note 1. Organization and Basis of Presentation</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Organization</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG has four principal direct wholly owned subsidiaries: PSE&amp;G, Power, Energy Holdings and PSEG Services Corporation (Services).</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSE&amp;G is an operating public utility engaged principally in the transmission of electric energy and distribution of electric energy and natural gas in certain areas of New Jersey. PSE&amp;G is subject to
  regulation by the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities (BPU) and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC).</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSE&amp;G also owns PSE&amp;G Transition Funding LLC (Transition Funding) and PSE&amp;G Transition Funding II LLC (Transition Funding II), bankruptcy-remote entities that purchased certain transition
  property from PSE&amp;G and issued transition bonds secured by such property. The transition property consists principally of the rights to receive electricity consumption-based per kilowatt-hour (kWh) charges
  from PSE&amp;G electric distribution customers, which represent irrevocable rights to receive amounts sufficient to recover certain of PSE&amp;G&#146;s transition costs related to deregulation, as approved by the BPU.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Power is a multi-regional, wholesale energy supply company that integrates its generating asset operations and gas supply commitments with its wholesale energy, fuel supply, energy trading and
  marketing and risk management function through three principal direct wholly owned subsidiaries: PSEG Nuclear LLC (Nuclear), PSEG Fossil LLC (Fossil) and PSEG Energy Resources &amp; Trade LLC
  (ER&amp;T). Nuclear and Fossil own and operate generation and generation-related facilities. ER&amp;T is responsible for the day-to-day management of Power&#146;s portfolio. Fossil, Nuclear and ER&amp;T are subject to
  regulation by FERC, and certain Fossil subsidiaries are also subject to state regulation. Nuclear is also subject to regulation by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC).</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Energy Holdings has two principal, direct, wholly owned subsidiaries: PSEG Global L.L.C. (Global), which owns and operates international and domestic projects engaged in the generation and
  distribution of energy and PSEG Resources L.L.C. (Resources), which has invested primarily in energy-related leveraged leases. Energy Holdings also owns Enterprise Group Development Corporation
  (EGDC), a commercial real estate property management business.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Services</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Services provides management and administrative and general services to PSEG and its subsidiaries. These include accounting, treasury, risk management, planning, information technology, tax, law,
  corporate secretarial, human resources, investor relations, corporate communications and certain other services. Services charges PSEG and its subsidiaries for the cost of work performed and services
  provided pursuant to the terms and conditions of intercompany service agreements.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">17</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.2mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Basis of Presentation</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The respective financial statements included herein have been prepared pursuant to the rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q.
  Certain information and note disclosures normally included in financial statements prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States (GAAP) have been condensed
  or omitted pursuant to such rules and regulations. These Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements and Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes) should be read in conjunction
  with, and update and supplement matters discussed in PSEG&#146;s, PSE&amp;G&#146;s, Power&#146;s and Energy Holdings&#146; respective Annual Reports on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2006 and Quarterly
  Reports on Form 10-Q and Form 10-Q/A for the quarter ended March 31, 2007.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The unaudited condensed consolidated financial information furnished herein reflects all adjustments which are, in the opinion of management, necessary to fairly state the results for the interim
  periods presented. All such adjustments are of a normal recurring nature. The year-end Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets were derived from the audited Consolidated Financial Statements included
  in the Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2006.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Reclassifications</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Certain reclassifications have been made to the prior quarter financial statements to conform to the current quarter presentation. The reclassifications relate primarily to PSE&amp;G&#146;s determination, during
  the fourth quarter of 2006, that the revenues and expenses related to one of its contracts that had been recorded on a gross basis would more appropriately be recorded on a net basis in Operating Revenues
  based upon the provisions of Emerging Issues Task Force (EITF) 99-19, &#147;Reporting Revenue Gross as a Principal versus Net as an Agent.&#148; Therefore, prior amounts have been reclassified, resulting in
  reductions of $44 million and $101 million in both Operating Revenues and Energy Costs for the quarter and six months ended June 30, 2006, respectively, for PSEG and PSE&amp;G, with no impact on
  Operating Income.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=note2>Note 2. Recent Accounting Standards</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>The following accounting standards were issued by the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB), but have not yet been adopted by PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings.</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (SFAS) No. 157, &#147;Fair Value Measurements&#148; (SFAS 157)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In September 2006, the FASB issued SFAS 157, which provides a single definition of fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value and expands disclosures about fair value measurements.
  Prior to SFAS 157, guidance for applying fair value was incorporated into several accounting pronouncements. SFAS 157 emphasizes that fair value is a market-based measurement, not an entity-specific
  measurement, and sets out a fair value hierarchy that distinguishes between assumptions based on market data obtained from independent sources (observable inputs) and those based on an entity&#146;s own
  assumptions (unobservable inputs). Under SFAS 157, fair value measurements are disclosed by level within that hierarchy, with the highest priority being quoted prices in active markets. While this
  statement does not require any new fair value measurements, the application of this statement will change current practice for some fair value measurements.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">This statement also nullifies the guidance in footnote 3 of EITF Issue No. 02-3, &#147;Issues Involved in Accounting for Derivative Contracts Held for Trading Purposes and Contracts Involved in Energy
  Trading and Risk Management Activities&#148; (EITF 02-3). The guidance in footnote 3 applies to derivative instruments measured at fair value at initial recognition, and it precludes immediate recognition in
  earnings of an unrealized gain or loss, measured as the difference between the transaction price and the fair value of the</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">18</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</B></FONT></P>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">instrument at initial recognition, if the fair value of the instrument is determined using significant unobservable inputs. Under EITF 02-3, an entity cannot recognize an unrealized gain or loss at inception of
  a derivative instrument unless the fair value of that instrument is obtained from a quoted market price in an active market or is otherwise evidenced by comparison to other observable current market
  transactions or based on a valuation technique incorporating observable market data. SFAS 157 requires that the principles of fair value measurement apply for derivatives and other financial instruments at
  initial recognition and in all subsequent periods.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">SFAS 157 is effective for financial statements issued for fiscal years beginning after November 15, 2007. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are currently assessing the potential impact of SFAS
  157 on their respective consolidated financial positions and results of operations.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>SFAS No. 159, &#147;The Fair Value Option for Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities&#148; (SFAS 159)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In February 2007, the FASB issued SFAS 159, which permits entities to measure many financial instruments and certain other items at fair value that are not currently required to be measured at fair
  value. An entity will report unrealized gains and losses on items where the fair value option has been elected in earnings at each subsequent reporting date. The objective is to improve financial reporting by
  providing entities with the opportunity to mitigate volatility in reported earnings caused by measuring related assets and liabilities differently without having to apply complex hedge accounting provisions.
  The decision about whether to elect the fair value option is applied instrument by instrument, with a few exceptions; the decision is irrevocable; and the decision is required to be applied to entire
  instruments and not to portions of instruments.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The statement requires disclosures that facilitate comparisons (a) between entities that choose different measurement attributes for similar assets and liabilities and (b) between assets and liabilities in
  the financial statements of an entity that selects different measurement attributes for similar assets and liabilities.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">SFAS 159 is effective for financial statements issued for fiscal years beginning after November 15, 2007. Upon implementation, an entity shall report the effect of the first remeasurement to fair value as
  a cumulative effect adjustment to the opening balance of Retained Earnings. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are currently assessing the potential impact of SFAS 159 on their respective
  consolidated financial positions and results of operations.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>FASB Staff Position FSP No. FIN 39-1, &#147;Amendment of FASB Interpretation No. 39&#148; (FSP 39-1)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG and Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In April 2007, the FASB issued FSP 39-1, which permits an entity to offset cash collateral paid or received against fair value amounts recognized for derivative instruments held with the same
  counterparty under the same master netting arrangement. Currently, PSEG and Power offset derivative contracts under master netting arrangements in accordance with FIN 39, &#147;Offsetting of Amounts
  Related to Certain Contracts,&#148; but do not net these balances with cash collateral positions. Under this FSP, PSEG and Power would be required to net cash collateral with the corresponding net derivative
  balance or elect to show all fair values gross.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">FSP 39-1 is effective for fiscal years beginning after November 15, 2007 and must be applied retroactively to all financial statements presented, unless it is impracticable to do so. PSEG and Power are
  currently evaluating the potential impact of FSP 39-1 on their respective financial positions. PSEG and Power expect no impact to their respective results of operations.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">19</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.2mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>The following new accounting standards were adopted by PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings during 2007.</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.2mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>FASB Interpretation No. 48, &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes&#151;an Interpretation of FASB Statement 109&#148; (FIN 48)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In July 2006, the FASB issued FIN 48, which prescribes a model for how a company should recognize, measure, present and disclose in its financial statements uncertain tax positions that the company
  has taken or expects to take on a tax return. Under FIN 48, the financial statements reflect expected future tax consequences of such positions presuming the tax authorities&#146; full knowledge of the position
  and all relevant facts. FIN 48 permits recognition of the benefit of tax positions only when it is &#147;more likely-than-not&#148; that the position is sustainable based on the merits of the position. It further limits the
  amount of tax benefit to be recognized to the largest amount of benefit that is greater than 50% likely of being realized. FIN 48 also requires explicit disclosures about uncertainties in income tax positions,
  including a detailed roll-forward of unrecognized tax benefits taken that do not qualify for financial statement recognition.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">FIN 48 was effective January 1, 2007. In general, companies recorded the change in net assets that resulted from the application of FIN 48 as an adjustment to Retained Earnings. However, for PSE&amp;G,
  because any charges to income arising from the adoption of FIN 48 should be recoverable in future rates, the offset to any incremental PSE&amp;G liability was recorded as a Regulatory Asset rather than
  Retained Earnings. The following table presents the impact at January 1, 2007 on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets for PSEG and its subsidiaries as a result of implementing FIN 48:</FONT></P>
<table cellspacing="0" style="margin-left:4.39%;margin-right:4.39%;width:91.22%;" >
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD style="width:54.79%;"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:6.01%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:4.71%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:6.56%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:9.60%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="bottom">
    <TD align="center">
    <P style="text-indent:-3.5mm; margin:0 0 0 3.5mm; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="6" align="center" style="border-bottom:solid 0.2mm Black; "><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.1mm; "><B>
      PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="6" align="center" style="border-bottom:solid 0.2mm Black; "><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.1mm; "><B>
      Power</B></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="6" align="center" style="border-bottom:solid 0.2mm Black; "><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.1mm; "><B>
      Energy<br>Holdings</B></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="6" align="center" style="border-bottom:solid 0.2mm Black; "><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.1mm; "><B>
      PSEG<br>Consolidated</B></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

  <TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>
      Balance Sheet</B></FONT></P></TD>

    <TD colspan="27" align="center"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.1mm; "><B>
      (Millions)</B></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>


  <TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#e5ffff">
    <TD>
    <P style="text-indent:-3.5mm; margin:0 0 0 3.5mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Increase to Long-Term Accrued Taxes</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      $</FONT></P></TD>

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">There was no impact on earnings for PSE&amp;G. For additional information relating to the impacts of FIN 48, see Note 11. Income Taxes.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In May 2007, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position No. FIN 48-1, which provides guidance on how an enterprise should determine whether a tax position is effectively settled for the purpose of
  recognizing previously unrecognized tax benefits. The adoption of this FSP did not have a material impact on the financial statements of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power or Energy Holdings.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>FSP No. FAS 13-2, &#147;Accounting for a Change or Projected Change in the Timing of Cash Flows Relating to Income Taxes Generated by a Leveraged Lease Transaction&#148; (FSP 13-2)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In July 2006, the FASB issued FSP 13-2, which addressed how a change or projected change in the timing of cash flows relating to income taxes generated by a leveraged lease transaction affects the
  accounting by a lessor for that lease. The FSP amends SFAS 13, &#147;Accounting for Leases,&#148; stating that a change in the timing of the above referenced cash flows must be reviewed at least annually or more
  frequently, if events or circumstances indicate a change in timing is probable. If a change in timing has</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">20</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</B></FONT></P>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">occurred, or is projected to occur, the rate of return and the allocation of income to positive investment years must be recalculated from the inception of the lease.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The guidance in this FSP was adopted on January 1, 2007. The cumulative effect of applying the provisions of this FSP is reported as an adjustment to the beginning balance of Retained Earnings as of
  the date of adoption. As a result of implementing FSP 13-2, upon adoption PSEG and Energy Holdings each recognized a reduction in Investment in Leveraged Leases of $69 million, a reduction in
  Deferred Income Taxes of $2 million and a reduction in Retained Earnings of $67 million.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The impact to earnings resulting from the adoption of FSP 13-2 for the quarter and six months ended June 30, 2007 was an after-tax decrease of $3 million and $6 million, respectively, for both PSEG
  and Energy Holdings.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=note3>Note 3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Impairments</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Discontinued Operations</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Lawrenceburg Energy Center (Lawrenceburg)</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On May 16, 2007, Power completed the sale of Lawrenceburg, a 1,096-megawatt, gas-fired combined cycle electric generating plant located in Lawrenceburg, Indiana, to AEP Generating Company, a
  subsidiary of American Electric Power Company, Inc.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The sale price for the facility and inventory was $325 million. The transaction resulted in an after-tax charge to Power&#146;s earnings of approximately $208 million and was reflected as a charge to
  Discontinued Operations in the fourth quarter of 2006.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Lawrenceburg&#146;s operating results for the quarter and six months ended June 30, 2007 and 2006, which were reclassified to Discontinued Operations, are summarized below:</FONT></P>

<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Electroandes S.A. (Electroandes)</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In March 2007, Global announced that it is exploring a potential sale of Electroandes, a hydro-electric generation and transmission company in Peru. Global owns approximately 100% of Electroandes.
  Electroandes owns and operates four hydro-generation plants with total capacity of 180 megawatts and 437 miles of electric transmission lines. In June 2007, based on the strong investor interest in this
  project as seen in the auction process to date, Energy Holdings reclassified the investment to Discontinued Operations.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">21</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</B></FONT></P>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">It is anticipated that a sale will close by the end of 2007, subject to regulatory approvals. As of June 30, 2007, the book value of Electroandes was approximately $166 million.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The 2007 and 2006 operating results for Global&#146;s assets in Electroandes have been reclassified to Discontinued Operations. In conjunction with the reclassification to Discontinued Operations,
  Electroandes recorded a $19 million income tax expense in the second quarter of 2007 related to the discontinuation of applying Accounting Principles Board (APB) Opinion No. 23, &#147;Accounting for
  Income Taxes&#151;Special Areas,&#148; as the income generated by Electroandes is no longer expected to be indefinitely reinvested.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Electroandes&#146; operating results for the quarter and six months ended June 30, 2007 and 2006 are summarized below:</FONT></P>

<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Elektrocieplownia Chorzow Elcho Sp. Z o.o. (Elcho) and Elektrownia Skawina SA (Skawina)</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On May 29, 2006, Global completed the sale of its interest in two coal-fired plants in Poland, Elcho and Skawina. Proceeds, net of transaction costs, were $476 million, resulting in a gain of $228 million
  net of tax expense of $142 million. The 2006 operating results for Global&#146;s assets in Poland have been reclassified to Discontinued Operations.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Elcho&#146;s and Skawina&#146;s operating results for the quarter and six months ended June 30, 2006 are summarized below:</FONT></P>

<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Dispositions</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In December 2006, Power recorded a pre-tax impairment loss of $44 million to write down four turbines to their estimated realizable value and reclassified them to Assets Held for Sale on Power&#146;s
  Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet. In April 2007, Power sold the four turbines to a third party and received proceeds of approximately $40 million, which approximates the recorded book value.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">22</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:1.4mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Global</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Thermal Energy Development Partnership, L.P. (Tracy Biomass)</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On December 22, 2006, Global entered into an agreement to sell its 34.5% interest in Tracy Biomass for approximately $7 million. The sale closed on January 26, 2007 and resulted in a 2007 pre-tax
  gain of approximately $7 million ($6 million after-tax).</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Rio Grande Energia S. A. (RGE)</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On May 10, 2006, Global entered into an agreement with Companhia Paulista de Force Luz (CPFL) to sell its 32% ownership interest in RGE, a Brazilian electric distribution company. The transaction
  closed on June 23, 2006 and gross proceeds of $185 million were received. The transaction resulted in a pre-tax write-down of $263 million ($177 million after-tax), primarily related to the devaluation of the
  Brazilian Real subsequent to Global&#146;s acquisition of its interests in RGE in 1997.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Impairment</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Venezuela</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG has indirect ownership interests in two generating facilities in Maracay and Cagua, Venezuela that have a total capacity of 120 MW. The projects are owned and operated by Turboven Company
  Inc. (Turboven), an entity which is jointly-owned by Global (50%) and Corporacion Industrial de Energia (CIE). Global also has a 9% indirect interest in Turbogeneradores de Maracay through a
  partnership with CIE.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">During Global&#146;s 2006 year-end review of its equity method investments, management concluded that due to the current political situation in Venezuela, it was probable that Global would not be able to
  recover all of its capitalized costs associated with its investments in Venezuela. Therefore, Global recorded a pre-tax impairment loss of approximately $7 million to write down these investments in the
  fourth quarter of 2006.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In January 2007, the Venezuelan government announced its intention to nationalize certain sectors of Venezuelan industry and commerce, including certain foreign-owned energy and communications
  companies. In a subsequent press release, Turboven was named as one of the companies that Venezuela intended to nationalize. Since these announcements, Venezuela has proceeded to nationalize certain
  companies. Global recently entered into preliminary valuation discussions with the government of Venezuela as part of the nationalization efforts. As of June 30, 2007, the book value of these investments
  was approximately $34 million. No assurances can be given as to whether Global can recover the current book value of the investments.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">23</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.2mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=note4>Note 4. Earnings Per Share (EPS)</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Diluted EPS is calculated by dividing Net Income by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding, including shares issuable upon exercise of stock options outstanding under
  PSEG&#146;s stock option plans and upon payment of performance units. The following table shows the effect of these stock options and performance units on the weighted average number of shares outstanding
  used in calculating diluted EPS:</FONT></P>
<table cellspacing="0" style="margin-left:0.00%;margin-right:0.00%;width:100.00%;" >

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Dividend payments on common stock for the quarters ended June 30, 2007 and 2006 were $0.585 and $0.57 per share, respectively, and totaled approximately $148 million and $143 million respectively.
  Dividend payments on common stock for the six months ended June 30, 2007 and 2006 were $1.17 and $1.14 per share, respectively, and totaled approximately $296 million and $286 million, respectively.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=note5>Note 5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Guaranteed Obligations</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Power contracts for electricity, natural gas, oil, coal, pipeline capacity, transportation and emission allowances and engages in risk management activities through ER&amp;T. These activities primarily involve
  the purchase and sale of energy and related products under transportation, physical, financial and forward contracts at fixed and variable prices. These transactions are executed with numerous
  counterparties and brokers. Counterparties and brokers may require guarantees, cash or cash-related instruments to be deposited on these transactions as described below.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Power has unconditionally guaranteed payments by its subsidiaries, ER&amp;T and PSEG Power New York Inc. (Power New York) in commodity-related transactions to support current exposure, interest
  and other</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">24</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</B></FONT></P>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">costs on sums due and payable in the ordinary course of business. These payment guarantees are provided to counterparties in order to obtain credit. Under these agreements, guarantees cover lines of
  credit between entities and are often reciprocal in nature. The exposure between counterparties can move in either direction. The face value of the guarantees outstanding as of June 30, 2007 and December
  31, 2006 was approximately $1.6 billion.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In order for Power to incur a liability for the face value of the outstanding guarantees, ER&amp;T and Power New York would have to fully utilize the credit granted to them by every counterparty to whom
  Power has provided a guarantee and all of ER&amp;T&#146;s and Power New York&#146;s contracts would have to be &#147;out-of-the-money&#148; (if the contracts are terminated, Power would owe money to the counterparties).
  The probability of all contracts at ER&amp;T and Power New York being simultaneously &#147;out-of-the-money&#148; is highly unlikely due to offsetting positions within the portfolio. For this reason, the current exposure
  at any point in time is a more meaningful representation of the potential liability to Power under these guarantees if ER&amp;T and/or Power New York were to default. This current exposure consists of the net
  of accounts receivable and accounts payable and the forward value on open positions, less any margins posted. The current exposure from such liabilities was $462 million and $518 million as of June 30,
  2007 and December 31, 2006, respectively.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Power is subject to counterparty collateral calls related to commodity contracts and is subject to certain creditworthiness standards as guarantor under performance guarantees for ER&amp;T&#146;s agreements.
  Changes in commodity prices, including fuel, emissions allowances and electricity, can have a material impact on margin requirements under such contracts. As of June 30, 2007 and December 31, 2006,
  Power had the following margin posted and received to satisfy collateral obligations and support various contractual and environmental obligations, which were primarily in the form of letters of credit:</FONT></P>
<table cellspacing="0" style="margin-left:13.16%;margin-right:13.16%;width:73.68%;" >
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD style="width:53.44%;"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:6.24%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:10.32%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="bottom">
    <TD align="center">
    <P style="text-indent:-3.5mm; margin:0 0 0 3.5mm; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="6" align="center" style="border-bottom:solid 0.2mm Black; "><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.1mm; "><B>
      As of<br>June 30,<br>2007</B></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>

      As of<br>December 31,<br>2006</B></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

  <TR valign="bottom">
    <TD align="center">
    <P style="text-indent:-3.5mm; margin:0 0 0 3.5mm; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="13" align="center"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.1mm; "><B>
      (Millions)</B></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>


  <TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#e5ffff">
    <TD>
    <P style="text-indent:-3.5mm; margin:0 0 0 3.5mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Margin Posted</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">

    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD align="right"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
       197</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
